Award.AwardTitle: Semi-annual Workshop in Dynamical Systems and Related Topics at Penn State
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for participants in the "Workshop in Dynamical Systems and Related Topics" for years 2013, 2014, 2015, and 2016. This is a long-standing series of conferences that are held each fall at Pennsylvania State University-University Park. The theme of the Penn State dynamics workshop varies from year to year; the focus areas include smooth ergodic theory, rigidity theory, smooth group actions, and classical mechanics.

The format of the conference provides ample opportunities for young mathematicians to present their work and otherwise to participate fully in conference activities. The bulk of the support goes to graduate students, postdocs, young faculty and women. A specific feature of the conference in the odd years is the announcement of the winner of the bi-yearly Michael Brin Prize in Dynamical Systems, endowed by the father of one the founders of Google, Professor Emeritus of the University of Maryland Michael Brin, and a special session featuring talks on the winner's work by the leading international experts in the area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Fall Workshop in Dynamical Systems and Related Topics represents Penn State's half of the Semiannual Workshop in Dynamical Systems and Related Topics, co-sponsored by the dynamics groups of Penn State and University of Maryland, College Park. The Penn State meeting takes place each fall since its inception in 1990, and the Maryland meeting is held each spring since 1992. These days they are major conferences in dynamical systems in the United States that attract many outstanding researchers as well as many young scientists, postdocs and graduate students. The talks given at these workshops cover essentially all areas of dynamics and represent the front line of research.

Among the past speakers at the fall conference were prominent mathematicians such as A. Avila, J. Mather, C. Liverani, N. Chernov, A. Delshams, S. Jitomirskaya, L. Polterovich, N. Sibony, J. Smillie, M. Lyubich, R. de la Llave, K. Khanin, R. Krikorian, J. Franks, K. Burns, S. Newhouse, F. Ledrappiers, K. Petersen, C. Matheus, M. Shub, R. Spatzier, M. Pollicott, P. Sarnak, A. Wilkinson, E. Lindenstrauss, A. Eskin, in addition to many outstanding members of the Penn State and Maryland groups.

In all our meetings we have  included talks from widely varying areas of dynamical systems and related areas in geometry, analysis, topology, etc. The highlights of 2013 and 2015 meetings were presentations of the 4th and the 5th Michael Brin Prize in Dynamical Systems to Omri Sarig and Federico Rodriguez Hertz. The 2013 meeting featured a special session dedicated to the 70th birthday of John Franks. The 2014 meeting was dedicated to the 70th birthday of Anatole Katok and his 50 years of research in dynamical systems. Additional funds for this meeting were provided by Penn State Department of Mathematics since this meeting had more participants than usual. The 2016 meeting featured a presentation of the 1st Dynamical Systems Prize for Young Mathematicians to Simon Filip and three talks dedicated to his work.

A primary goal of our conference is to contribute to the training of graduate students and recent Ph.D.s and to their integration into the dynamics community. A special emphasis was made on supporting graduate students, junior mathematicians and women and giving them an opportunity to speak. Typically 15 to 20 graduate students attend the conference and 4 to 8 of them give short talks on the recommendation of their advisors. We generally schedule talks by students and recent Ph.D. recipients on the second and third days of the conference to ensure the greatest potential audience. Sometimes we have parallel sessions, but never more than two speakers at a time. In organizing the conference a special attention is given to reimbursing expenses of graduate students. In addition to the usual lodging coverage we provide the cost of transportation for junior participants driving in carpools. The book exhibit that has accompanied our conference for about 20 years provides an important educational component.
